Dialogue.Stage Direction: Far out in space hangs a segmented structure built solely to receive and transmit data across the space ways. A black dart-shaped craft approaches it and docks. Three men carry boxes of equipment into the beacon. Outside the beacon, two space-walkers attach magnetic charges its hull and finally a rocket propulsion unit.

Dialogue.Line: Dervish! Dervish!
(a thin man) We've nearly finished.
About time.
My men are just coming. We'll detonate by radio beam.
Right. Hurry it up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: All the men return to the ship. It undocks and moves away. Shortly afterwards a radio signal is sent and beacon Alpha One goes KaBOOM!

Another ship is travelling through space. This one is thin and wide, with military insignia V41-LO. The flight deck is split into an upper command bridge with silver-haired General Hermack in charge, and a lower technical area.

Dialogue.Line: Everything all right, Penn?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: played by  Jack May

Dialogue.Line: Fine, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The young  George Layton with a zapata moustache.

Dialogue.Line: Fine.
(American) You sent for me, sir?
Ah yes, Ian. Sit down.
Thank you.
Any information on that beacon signal yet?
No, sir. There's been no response to the secondary emergency circuits. either.
No, there wouldn't be.
Sir?
What do you think has happened to that beacon?
Well, it's difficult to say, sir. It could be a failure in the solar energy store.
No. The emergency power would operate and we'd get a may day signal.
Well. Oh, you don't think this is a mechanical failure, sir?
No. No, I don't. These beacons are practically fool proof.
You got any ideas?
Yes, I have. And I must be right. Argonite! These beacons are almost entirely constructed of argonite.
Of course, sir. What are you going to do about it?

Attention all personnel. This is General Hermack. Your V-ship is now fifty days and many billions of miles out from Earth. You're entering the fourth sector of our galaxy. In this sector for some time now, Earth Government has been aware that a highly organised gang of criminals have been roaming the space ways, and preying upon defenceless cargo ships. The main target of these criminals is argonite, the most valuable mineral known to man and so far only found on the planets of the Fourth Sector. A government space beacon marking the approaches to the planet New Sarum has ceased transmitting its navigation signal. These beacons, as you know, are constructed of argonite. It is my belief that the criminals are attacking the government navigation beacons and plundering the argonite. There can be no other explanation for its failure. This being the case, I have decided to abandon our present mission and to investigate the missing beacon in the New Sarum sector. I want all section commanders on the bridge at twenty hundred hours sector four solar time. Resume normal duties until then.
There are eighteen space beacons quite scattered across this sector, sir.
Seventeen, Ian, until the one at New Sarum's replaced.
Seventeen. And they're millions of miles apart. So how can we be sure which one the pirates are likely to attack next?
We can't.
Well, exactly. The odds are seventeen to one against us being in the right place at the right time.
Ah! With our speed, I think we can cut those odds a bit. Now, there are four beacons in the Pliny solar system here. That is where we'll start our patrol.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is a dart-shaped craft docked to this beacon now. It is the same routine as at Alpha One.

Dialogue.Line: Come on! Speed it up.
Caven, I don't like this.
Nobody's asking you to like it. Just get those scissor charges laid into position.
If we attack any more beacons, we'll have the whole of the Interstellar Space Corps in this sector.
Look, as of this moment, the Space Corps has its hands full of trouble. Bush fire wars in three different sectors. There's never been a better time for getting rich.
Right, lads. Now, we'll lay four charges along the main axis, then we'll attach booster charges around the hull. Okay.
You're a good engineer, Dervish. Just do your job and leave the Space Corps to me, eh?
Okay. But I worked ten years for Earth Government.
You should've stayed with them. They'd have given you a pension.
Attacking Government property is one crime they make sure never pays.
Sixteen hundred tons of pure argonite pays all right, Dervish. To me this is like a floating bank.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The charges are laid.

Dialogue.Line: What range are the forward scanners set for, Penn?
Fifteen hundred, sir.
Well reset them at two thousand. Right?
Very good, sir.
And keep a sharp eye on that screen. There are lots of rogue asteroids in the Pliny system.
Oh, and one thing more. Make sure the Minnow ships are fully fuelled, and put the detonation heads on their missiles. Report back as soon as that is done.
We're approaching the Pliny system now, sir. We've made scanner contact with the four beacons. They're functioning normally.
Ah good. Now this planet Ta, here, is the main one in the system. We'll orbit here for a few weeks and see what happens.
So that's Ta, huh?
You've heard of it?
Yeah. It's the head quarters of the Issigri Mining Corporation. The most productive planet in the entire galaxy.
Madeleine Issigri has built quite a place there. Which is one reason for basing ourselves in the Pliny system.
Why's that a reason, sir?
Well, if we're out here long, Ian, the men will need somewhere for rest and recreation. Deep space sickness is the one thing we can't chance.
Major Warne.
What is it, Penn?
I've got a contact, sir, at beacon Alpha Seven.
Well, hold on it. Any identification?
No, sir. Too far away.
Ah, it's a space ship right enough. Check Central Flight Information, Ian, and see if anyone should be out there.
Right, sir.
Change course for beacon Alpha Seven. Bridge to Power Room, I want ten seconds main boost.
According to Flight Information, sir, there should be no ships in the area within the next seventeen days.
Well, whoever they are, they've not yet reported to Central Flight Information.
Do you think it's the pirates?

Yes, it could be. Though some of these commercial flights don't always like to report their whereabouts, for reasons of their own. Anyway, we shall soon know. (Meanwhile, the pirate ship undocks from Alpha Seven.)
She's backing off, sir.
Keep track of her.
She's moving quite fast, sir.
Got a good turn of speed for a commercial.
Is beacon Alpha Seven still functioning?
Yes, sir. Very strong signal.
Well, that's something.
Maybe they were just picking up emergency supplies, sir. Some of these beacons do carry reserve medical and oxygen equipment.
Sir, I've got another signal coming in now. It's a UHF!
UHF? But that's reserved for demolition teams.
Well, put it on audio.
Yes, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Beacon Alpha Seven explodes.

Dialogue.Line: Alpha Seven's broken up, sir.
Ah. Right under our noses. Main boost.
Lost the beacon, sir. No more signal.
No, there won't be. It's probably in a dozen separate bits by now.
Keep full contact with that pirate ship.
Yes, sir.
At least we can be sure they don't get away. Ian, give me a projected arrival time.
Three hours, sir. Maybe I can get a visual on the main scanner.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The pirate ship appears on the viewscreen, towing beacon debris.

Dialogue.Line: There she is sir. And that's what's left of the beacon.
We've got them cold, Ian. We'll be onto them long before they get rid of that salvaged scrap.
Yeah, providing she doesn't see us approaching, sir.
They don't know
That ship looks fast
They don't know we're in the same area. What's wrong with the scanner?
Seem to be losing visual contact, sir.
The ship's moving away, sir.
What?
Just started to go, and the beacon debris's going with her.
Hold that contact, Penn.
It's no good, sir. She's going too fast.
They must have twice our speed!
Maybe the Minnows could hold her?
Not at this distance. They haven't the fuel.
Lost contact, sir.
Oh, hold the same course.
Sir.
Keep searching.
They must have attached rocket units to the beacon, sir, the way it moved off.
Yes. They're very well organised. They cut the beacon into several manageable pieces by means of scissor charges, then shoot the bits off to some pre-arranged collection point. Very clever.
And quick. It cuts down the time they're at risk. And they just burn out the Argonite at their leisure.
Ian, we shall have to rethink our tactics. We shall never catch them by normal patrol methods.
What else can we do, sir?
Man the beacons.
Man them?

It's the only answer. We'll drop small parties of four or five men on each beacon and give them rations and supplies for two months. Well, all these mark five beacons were designed as emergency survival centres.
Yes sir, but I don't think anybody has ever tried living on them. Some of these beacons are pretty primitive.
I'm not interested in men's comfort, Major. Set course for the nearest beacon.
Yes, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Lieutenant and four armed guards enter the beacon with survival packs. Warne follows.

Dialogue.Line: Here's your radio, Lieutenant. It's beamed automatically to main control. All you have to do in the event of trouble is press this button, right?
(Dark) Don't worry, I'll press it.
Remember your main job here is to give us the earliest possible warning in the event of the pirate ship approaching, right?
And after that, we fight them.
After that, I think you'll have to, Joe. Good Luck.
Thank you.
See you in about six weeks.
I hope.
Set a course for Alpha Nine.
Very good, sir.
I told Lieutenant Sorba we'd be back in about six weeks. sir.
Or much earlier if the pirates raid Alpha Four. How's morale on the picket?
Oh, it's pretty high, sir. I think they're hoping for the chance of a party.
They understand they have to shoot on sight?
Yes, sir, I told them. No, anybody poking their nose aboard Alpha Four will find plenty of trouble waiting for him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And with those words, the Tardis materialises in the beacon's computer bay. The soldiers are on the level below.

Dialogue.Line: Now we're going to be here for about six weeks. Settle down and keep your eyes open. Take care about
Sir.
What? What are you doing here? Why aren't you in the observation tower?
There's something in the computer bay, sir.
Something? Well, what do you mean by that?
I heard something in there, sir. A noise.
All right, we'd better check it out then. Come on.
Oh dear.
What's wrong?
Well, I don't think we're quite where I expected. Never mind. This looks very interesting.
Interesting? A piece of old machinery?
Yes. I've never seen a computer quite like this before, Jamie.
It looks like some sort of control room.
Yes, but what does it control?
Yeah. Well I think we'd better get out of here before somebody catches us.
Good idea. There's a door here.
No, Zoe. I meant in the Tardis.
Jamie, stop worrying. There's obviously nobody here.
Well, how do you know that?
Well, this machine is programmed to operate by itself.
Yes, but what does it do?

Well, I'm not sure Zoe, but I think we're on an unmanned spacecraft in a fixed orbit. We're too far away from anywhere to be a weather satellite. Let's see what clues we can find through here, shall we?
What's that?
What? (A floor panel lifts and Sorba starts shooting as the Doctor, Zoe and Jamie run out of the room.)
Nobody here, eh?
Now what are we going to do? The Tardis is in there.
There's only one thing we can do.
What?
Run!
Well, maybe next time you'll listen to me.
If there is a next time.
All right, there are only three of them and they can't get away. Hunt them down and don't forget. Shoot to kill.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The pirates have arrived.

Dialogue.Line: Alpha Four. Another present from the home planet's tax payers.
Same procedure as last time?
Yes, Dervish. But now that you've had a little practice, get those scissor charges laid a bit quicker, eh?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Energy weapons fire.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, what's that? Caven, those were blaster guns!
Get the crew in here at the double.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Our heroes run along companionways sealing the hatches behind them.

Dialogue.Line: Are you all right, Zoe?
Yes, I think so.
That should hold them for a little while.
But why are they trying to kill us? We haven't done anything.
No.
I don't know, but we're certainly not stopping to find out.
What's that? Look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A welding torch is cutting through the hatch.

Dialogue.Line: Come on. Let's find somewhere else to hide.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They go further on and secure another hatch.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, there's no way out of here.
What?
Look!
Oh Doctor, what can we do?
Well, I don't know. If we go down there we'll bump straight into them. I'm afraid we're trapped.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sorba's men have cut through the first hatch.

Dialogue.Line: All right, this way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The pirates shoot the soldiers in the back. Sorba is shot and he falls while pressing the call button on his radio.

Dialogue.Line: Thirty minutes from beacon Alpha Three, sir.
Right. Warn the picket to stand by on C deck, Ian.
Right, sir.
Emergency from Beacon Alpha Four, sir!
Sorba's being attacked.
Set course for Alpha Four. Try and get me a visual on the scanner, Ian.
On course, sir.
Bridge to Power House. I want main boost for as long as you can hold it without vapourising the motors.
This one's still alive.
So the Space Corps were too busy to bother about us, eh?
Shut up! I'm thinking.
There's no time for thinking. We've got to get out of here.
Four space Guards and an officer. What are they doing here?
There must be a cruiser in the area.
Not a big enough crew to defend the beacon but they must have been put on board for a reason.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Caven sees a box lying beside Sorba.

Dialogue.Line: What's this?
It looks like a fixed beam transmitter. Why, that's it. Well, they'll be on their way back here by now.
Then you'd better get moving.
Well, you don't still want the beacon cutting up?
That's what we came here to do.
Think about it!
Don't waste time. Get on with it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Caven shoots the transmitter.

Dialogue.Line: Could be their radio's packed up, sir.
Yes. Give me a projected arrival time.
Two hours twenty minutes.
I should have left a stronger picket.
Oh no, sir. We haven't the man power. Besides Sorba knew he could only hope to delay things.
I am going to get that gang of murdering thieves if I have to spend the next ten years out here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sorba wakes.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, Lieutenant, you're the last of the toy soldiers.
Shot in the back.
You mean we're disqualified. You don't want to play any more?
You can laugh now, but you won't get away with this.
Who's going to stop me, Lieutenant?
How did you get those decoys aboard?
Decoys?
Those three that lead us into your ambush.
Concussion, lieutenant? Or stalling for time?
You know who I'm talking about. They ran off into the aft companionway.
None of my men down there. Must be some of yours.
Sure. We were having a private training session with loaded thermite guns.
We did hear firing in the airlock. You mean there really is someone else in there?
I thought you'd planted them there.
Whoever they are, we've got no time to bother with them now.
I've laid the charges. Just fixing the rockets.
Good. If he can walk, get him out of here. If he can't, leave him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Caven shoots the lock of the hatch.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing?
Just sealing a coffin, Dervish. **[Beacon Alpha Four compartment]**.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: On the other side of the hatch.

Dialogue.Line: I wish I could hear what they're saying.
I think they're trying to burn through it.
Just a minute. I think they've gone away.
I don't understand. Why didn't they come in here after us?
Aye, they must've known we were trapped. Why not finish us off?
They didn't seem very friendly, did they? Oh!
What's the matter?
Well, it's hot. You try.
Ah. No, thank you.
I told you they were trying to burn through it.
Well, why haven't they?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They hear a clang.

Dialogue.Line: What's that?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Another clang.

Dialogue.Line: There's something moving out there.
It sounds as if somebody's on the hull.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The pirates are fastening the charges and propulsion units.

Dialogue.Line: What are they doing?
I don't know Jamie. Perhaps they're cleaning the windows.
Oh. Eh?
Look, why don't we sneak back to the Tardis and get out of here?
Aye, while we've still got the chance.
A sensible idea, Zoe. You're sure there's nobody out there?
I haven't heard anybody for ages. Come on.
Mind out, it's hot.
Well, it's not hot any more.
What?
I can't unlock it.
Let me do it, Zoe. You'll have to eat more porridge.
Jamie, I don't think it's any use. You know what I think they've done?
What?
They've welded the lock! We're prisoners!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The pirate ship leaves the beacon.

Dialogue.Line: Penn, give me a bearing on that pirate ship.
I can't pick her up, sir.
What?
The debris from that beacon's jammed the signals.
Oh Penn, you are an incompetent, useless
Keep trying, Penn.
Yes, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Warne joins Hermack at the coffee machine at the side of the bridge section.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, coffee?
Yes please, sir. Thank you.
All right, I know. The men are doing their best.
General?
Isn't that what you were going to say?
Something like that, yeah.
You see? They're moving out of range already.
If only we could have sustained continual main boost, it might have been a different story. They must have a base somewhere in this system. We're more than fifty days out from home planet.
Quite. They can have main boost the whole time. Our only chance is getting close enough to launch the Minnows.
Or locate their base. They must have dispatched pieces of that beacon to it. If we could just locate one of the pieces.
Can't be done. If those auxiliary rockets cut out, we've nowhere to track on. You see? There's nothing left now.
We've got the tactile scanner, sir.
That would be like looking for a single speck of dust at the bottom of an argonite mine.
Do you think there's any chance they're still alive out there?
You mean Sorba's men?
Yeah.
I doubt it. I doubt if anyone's alive on that beacon now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As the sections of the beacon float along in formation, three figures lie unconscious in the rearmost one.

Dialogue.Line: Major Warne!
What is it, Penn?
Rocket ship, sir.
Are you sure?
No doubt of it, sir, and she's right in the area where beacon Alpha Four went up.
Right, can I get it on the TS?
We should be able to, sir. Bearing starboard nineteen from SDC.
Nineteen SDC.
What is it, Ian?
Something on the radar, sir.
The pirates?
Well, if it is, there's something wrong with their ship. She's hardly moving.
But they don't even know we're in the same area.
Oh I don't know, sir. They must be aware that there's a V-ship in the system. They ran into our picket on Alpha Four. Which is why. somehow, I don't think this could be their ship.
But according to flight information, there should be nothing in this solar system for the next eighty hours.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Warne gets an image on a rear monitor.

Dialogue.Line: There she is, sir. And that isn't the ship we saw before.
No, it isn't. Can you get a closer shot?
That's one of the old C-class freighters, sir. I didn't know they were still flying.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: This ship is homely, with a jacket slung over the back of the captain's chair. A hot hard-boiled bell rings and an egg drops out of a dispenser chute. A space cowboy in checked shirt and neckerchief enters singing 'Somewhere Over the Rainbow'. Think the sort of character Gabby Hayes used to play. He puts the egg in an egg cup and sits in his chair with the full breakfast tray on his lap. Smoke comes out of a toaster. He throws away the charcoal offering.

Dialogue.Line: The last of me nutty sliced bread. Rubbishy new-fangled solar toasters!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The lights go dim. He thumps a panel and they come up again.

Dialogue.Line: Ah. That's better.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Just as he is taking the top off his egg, the Call light flashes. Milo puts on a headset.

Dialogue.Line: This is V forty one. V forty one calling LIZ seventy nine. LIZ seven nine, can you hear me?
LIZ seventy nine. LIZ seventy nine. I can hear you, V forty one. Go away!
What? Now listen. This is General Nikolai Hermack. Commander of the Space First Division. Give me your identity registration.
A general, a real general. Oh, General, why don't you take yourself off? I'm trying to have my breakfast.
LIZ seventy nine, give me your identity registration. That is an order.
Oh come on, General, I lost that thing about thirty years ago. Why don't you go about your business and leave me alone.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Warne gets the data up on a monitor.

Dialogue.Line: That's LIZ seventy nine's registration, sir. She's a real old-timer. She's been afloat for about forty years.
Milo Clancey! I might have known.
You know him, sir?
Of him. Out in Reja Magnum, where I did my first tour, he was something of a legend. Milo Clancey! I have your identity registration here.
I'm very glad for you, General. That's great work. That's very good. Now, good day.
Listen, Clancey. Where are you from and where are you bound?
Might I ask, General, what in tarnations business that might be of yours?
Clancey, I'm coming alongside with a boarding party. I warn you, don't try and resist.
I won't tangle with you, General. You come on in and join the party. Oh, and mind you don't scratch your nice shiny white paint.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor wakes, and shakes Jamie.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie, Jamie.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor drags one of a pair of gas cylinders over to Zoe and Jamie.

Dialogue.Line: I've sent a guard aboard, sir, to pick up Clancey. I don't think he'll give us any trouble.
Yes. Well, he won't co-operate though. Ian, have you ever run across any of these old-timers?
No, sir.
They think they're a law unto themselves. They don't like the Space Corps either.
Why?

Well, these old mining prospectors like Clancey were the first men to go out into deep space. For a time they had the place to themselves, roaming the spaceways, looking for planets, jumping each other's claims. They were a wild breed, Ian, and they learned to live without the law.
And then the Space Corps came along and started to enforce law and order, right?
Yes, much to their resentment. Clancey must be the last of the type.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Milo enters.

Dialogue.Line: My, my, my. Well, they certainly do you slickers proud, don't they. It's like a whole floating fun palace up here.
Clancey, I am General Hermack.
Howdy!
And this is Major Warne, my ADC.
Major?
What are you doing in this system and why you are not on feedback to Central Flight Information?
Oh, am I not, General?
No.
Oh, no, you're right. You're right. I remember now. That old feedback of mine, it just sort of fell to bits about five year ago now.
Five years?
Or could it be ten? Yep. Certainly could be ten. I've been always meaning to get that thing fixed.
You know it's an offence to operate without a feedback to CFI?
An offence?
Right.
I didn't realise that, sonny, no. Oh dear, oh dear, oh dear. There are so many offences these days.
Clancey, what are you doing in this system?
Well, I am the head of the Milo Clancey Space Mining Company.
Yes, we know all about that. We have your identity registration here.
Oh, that must be great for you, General, to have all of those facts at your fingertips like that.
Get to the point, Clancey.
You would know the point if you'd been reading my reports I've been sending to you the last two years.
What do you mean?
Argonite pirates, that's what I mean, sonny.
Go on, Clancey.
Over the last two years, I have lost five floaters carrying argonite ore back to home planet. They were hijacked, General, and they were brought into this system.
You reported this, you say?
Ah, aye, I reported this, sonny. About a dozen times I reported it but it didn't do me any good, did it. So I said to myself, all right, all righty, I'll just have to do something about this myself.
How much argonite did you have on each floater?
I had a full load. Fifty thousand tons unrefined ore.
What makes you so sure your floaters were bought into this system?
Time, sonny, time. This system is the closest to where they left the spaceway. And my old floaters, they've got no propulsion units. They're unmanned. They don't move very fast, sonny.
I know that!

Oh, he's a good lad. He's a bright lad, this boy of yours. Good thinking. Is it all right if I blow my nose, or is that another offence? My old nose. I can't get used to all your fancy air-conditioning.
That's a pity, Clancey, but I'm afraid you'll have to put up with it a bit longer. Now, how long have you been in the area of beacon Alpha Four?
Beacon Alpha Four?
Yes.
Oh. Have you a chart, General?
Here.
Oh, that's where we are. Well, well, well. You see, my charts don't pick up these new fanged beacons. I don't trust them.
Just an astral pointer and a piece of string, huh?
That is right, sonny. Hey listen, I can't see beacon Alpha Four here either. That's what I'm telling you. They're unreliable. They're a waste of public money.
Beacon Alpha Four is not registering because it's not there any more.
The argonite pirates blew it up three hours ago.
Oh, did they so. That'd be for salvage I guess. Yeah, that would be it.
You don't seem very surprised, Clancey.

No, no, I'm not, General. This is clearing up a whole heap of things in my head. I can lose every floater I've got and your fancy Space Corps won't do a thing about it. But the government loses one government beacon and that's a different matter. Then you come running. That's what you're here now for
Well, if there is any truth in your story, Clancey, and we do catch up with the pirates, you'll be entitled to put in a claim for compensation.
If I waited for you to catch these critters, I'd catch my death of cold waiting forever. I should think this old crate of yours has about half the speed of a Beta Dart, right?
Our speed is classified information.
Oh, that may be, sonny, but this marauding band of sharks, you know they're using Beta Darts, one of the latest. You're in the wrong league, boys. Why don't you just go home where you came from.
How do you know what ship they have?
Because I crossed their thieving flight path a couple of times. And if my old Liz had any speed about her, I'd have rammed them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is standing on a box and looking through a porthole in the ceiling.

Dialogue.Line: Can you see anything, Doctor?
I'm coming down. Look out.
Well, what's on the other side? Could you see?
Jamie, I'm afraid that there's nothing on the other side. Just space. It appears that this machine we're on has been blown into about eight separate pieces.
Are you sure?
Well, of course I'm sure. Get up and look for yourself if you don't believe me.
Then that must have been the explosion.
Doctor, does that mean the Tardis is gone?
Yes, Jamie.
That means we'll never get it back.
I don't understand. Why would anybody want to blow up a space machine?
Sabotage perhaps.
But what about those men that tried to killed us?
I think they were here to defend the machine. That would explain why they were so unfriendly towards us.
Well, what you're saying is that we've landed ourselves in the middle of some sort of war in space.
Now we're just floating aimlessly on a bit of debris.
No, Zoe, not aimlessly. There appear to be rockets attached to each part of the machine. And they're all moving along together.
Hey?

Well, as you know, Jamie, when something explodes in space, all the pieces separate and go on separating indefinitely, but this machine has separated just so far, perhaps a mile, and now, as I say, they're all moving together at the same speed.
Because of the rockets. Oh, I see. So whoever broke up the machine is sending all the pieces to the same place?
It looks like it, Zoe.
Oh, so we can get back to the Tardis then? If it's only a mile away.
A mile in space, Jamie, with no oxygen or means of propulsion.
It might just as well be a thousand miles.
Oh, that's just fine then.
Have you got an idea, Doctor?
Shush, shush. Just a minute.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is a buzzing sound.

Dialogue.Line: Now what on earth is that?
Oh lookie here, General. If you've finished with all your fool questions, I've got work to do. I want to get back to my ship.
All right, Clancey, I'm sorry to have detained you.
Sir?
What? What, you mean I can go?
Of course.
That's great. That's very kind of you. I'll just say goodbye then, General. Goodbye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Milo leaves with an escort.

Dialogue.Line: The navigators are standing by for orders, sir.
Obviously you think I've done the wrong thing.
It's not for me to say, General.
You think I let Clancey go too easily.
I would have put him through the mind probe, sir.
That did occur to me. He does seem to be mixed up with these argonite pirates.
Too much.
You think he's in league with them?
It's possible, sir. You said he's no respecter of the law. That story about floaters and pirates could have just been a cover story.
I quite agree.
You agree, sir?
Oh yes, Ian. Not only do I think that Milo Clancey is in league with the argonite pirates, I think he is the mastermind behind the whole organisation, which is precisely why I let him go

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor prises open an equipment cover and frowns.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, what's he doing now?
I've no idea. Ask him.
Oh, what's the use? He's got his mysterious face on.
Well, I think he's just trying to keep our hopes up.
Hopes?
By looking busy. There's nothing anyone can do now. I'd say we've got a few hours at the outside.
What do you mean by a few hours?
Well, haven't you noticed, Jamie? Haven't you noticed how difficult it is to breathe properly now?
Bridge to armoury, this is Major Warne. I want a Minnow readied for immediate launching. Fit contact warheads to the Martian missiles.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A hatch opens in the 41 painted on the starboard wing, and a little ship that looks more like a mosquito than a minnow comes out. M5-V2 launches.

Dialogue.Line: Navigator Penn.
Sir?
Keep contact with Major Warne in the Minnow until he reports he's within visual range of LIZ seventy nine.
Very good, sir.
V-Master to X X one. Come in, Ian.
Okay, General. I'm following Clancey without his knowing.
Yes, but remember he's no fool. If he suspects he's being followed, you'll be in trouble. Meanwhile I'm going in to land on Ta. Relay reports to the nearest beacon.
Oh Doctor, can we have some more oxygen?
I'm afraid not, Zoe. We've got to conserve it.
Oh, what's the use. We'll never get out of this.
Come here, both of you. Look. Look at these.
What are they?
They're solar powered magnets. It's a force field.
Hey?
Well, don't you see. The explosive charges that blew this machine apart didn't damage its structure. They simply divided it along the lines of its electromagnetic fields.
How do you know?
Because there was no damage to the structure.
You mean the machine was built in separate sections and assembled in space by magnetism.
Yes, you see, Jamie, opposite poles attract and the same poles repel.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor demonstrates with a pair of magnets on strings from his pocket.

Dialogue.Line: You see? Try it. There.
Oh, so the explosion was just strong enough to break the magnetic attraction between each section?
Yes.
But that doesn't do us any good, does it?
But it just might, Jamie. Supposing I could step up the electromagnetic power enough to bridge the space between this section and the next.
You mean draw it towards us.
Yes, and then repeat the process with each section and so on until we reach the Tardis!
Hey, well, do you think you could do it?
Well, I've got a screwdriver.
Oh.
And I've got a slight knowledge of electromagnetism.
Yes, there's just one thing, Doctor.
Oh, Jamie, would you move this cylinder out of the way?
How do you know the next section to this one is an opposite pole?
Well I don't, Zoe.
Well, if it's similar, your idea won't work, will it? We'll just shoot off in the opposite direction.
Zoe, don't be such a pessimist.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Meanwhile, the V ship heads towards a planet.

Dialogue.Line: Thirteen hundred. X X 1 to V Master. I have made visual contact with LIZ seven nine. We're still orbiting in the same dimensional plane. Nothing further to report.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Transmission ends.

Dialogue.Line: It must be very uncomfortable after a few hours in one of those Minnows, General.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She tops up his glass.

Dialogue.Line: It is. Thank you. But then after a week you get quite used to it.
I thought so. LIZ seventy nine is Milo Clancey's ship.
Your records are very comprehensive.
Why is he being followed?
Well, I explained to you the purpose of this mission. I believe that Clancey has connection with the argonite pirates.
That seems unlikely.
Oh, why?
He has argonite mines on the planet Lobos.
Which I hear are pretty well worked out.
They used to say this planet was worked out, but I brought in new machinery and today it's the most productive in the galaxy.
I must say, I'm surprised to find you of all people defending Clancey.
Why?
Well, because of the rumours connecting him with the death of your father, Dom Issigri.
Well, I tried to prove that at the time but nobody knows what happened between them, so now I prefer to forget it.
But you took over the argonite holdings from your father and split away from Clancey.
Yes.
And now you run the most successful argonite mining business in the galaxy, while Clancey, because of your competition must be pretty nearly bankrupt.
Is that why you think he's taken up with piracy?
Well, jealousy of your great success would be a pretty strong motive. Unless of course, you disagree.
Oh, you may be right. But I haven't seen him since the day the partnership was dissolved, so well, I don't know what he feels.
Well, I can understand it. For a man like Clancey to be defeated by an attractive woman like you at his own game, he'd take any risk to get his revenge.
Well, I wouldn't like to think that that was true.
Your concern does you credit, but I'm convinced I shall have the proof I need within a few hours.
Really? How?
Warne has reported that Clancey is still on the same dimensional orbit as he was when we left him. Obviously he's expecting a rendezvous.
With a pirate ship?
I think so.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor lets some gas out of a cylinder.

Dialogue.Line: I think that's all we can spare.
How much longer?
I've nearly done it, Jamie. I've just got one more connection to make.
I hope it works.
Of course it will work. The theory is perfectly sound.
Aye, maybe. That wiring looks like a cat's cradle to me.
Yes, yes, it's a little bit of a mess, Jamie, but I can assure you it's thoroughly functional. Thoroughly functional. Here we are. Now you two had better hold on. Are you ready?
Yes, ready, Doctor.
Hold tight. Here we go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor pulls a lever and they are all pushed back.

Dialogue.Line: What's happened?
Oh Doctor, you've got it wrong! We're gathering speed!
I know! I know! I can't turn it off!
What?
Ah! No! I'm stuck. The power's too great.
Well, isn't it working?
Oh yes, it's working all right, but the wrong way! We're being sucked further into space!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And to prove it we see one segment go hurtling away from the other seven.

Dialogue.Line: Oh Doctor, for goodness sake do something!
I'm trying to, Zoe. I'm trying to.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor manages to push the lever back up again. They all fall to the floor, exhausted.

Dialogue.Line: Oh thank goodness.
Are we all right now?
Doctor?
No, Zoe, I'm afraid we're not. Even if I could reverse the magnetic field, I'm afraid we're too far away from the next section.
Then we're worse off now. Just floating hopelessly in space.
Yes. Oh, dear. What a silly idiot I am.
Well naturally, General, I'm prepared to give all the help I can. WARNE [on monitor]: Thirteen ten. X X One to V-Master.
Something must be happening. He's not due to report. WARNE [on monitor]: LIZ seven nine is now on retro-drive. She's linking with a section of Alpha Four. Standing by for orders.
You see? Clancey's in the collection area. He's awaiting the beacon sections.
It could be coincidence. He's seen the drifting wreckage and he's curious.
Madam, you'd need a ITM computer to work that out. No, this is the proof I need.
What are you going to do? Arrest him?
Could I use your audio board?
Of course.
V-Master to X X One. Can you hear me, Ian?
Yes, sir. LIZ seven nine is now completing the link-up. I'm standing by for orders.
Good. That means he can't make a sudden move. I want you to go in and arrest him.
Tell your man to be careful, General. Clancey has a terrible temper. He's likely to explode like glycerol trinitrate.
Ian, if he shows any sign of resistance, use your missiles. Otherwise, escort him back here. WARNE [on monitor]: I understand, sir.
Report back when the arrest is made.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Behind Hermack's back, Madeleine looks pleased.

Dialogue.Line: Stay still, the pair of you, unless you want to follow him.
Ah, Penn.
Sir?
Major Warne needs some assistance. I want you to take the ship out and stand off at twenty miles, just in case Clancey tries any tricks during the landing.
Very good, sir.
Aren't you going with your ship, General?
No, I shall be in charge of ground reception. Leave a section of guards, Penn, with short-ranged missiles.
Right, sir. How long shall I keep the ship in stand-off orbit, sir?
You can come in just as soon as Clancey hits the landing pad.
Sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Penn leaves.

Dialogue.Line: All this for one old man. You aren't taking any chances, are you.
That is why I'm a general, madam.
Well, what will happen to him?
Well, he'll be taken back to home planet and tried.
And end in a Nervan prison chamber.
Well, when Clancey turned pirate, he knew the penalties if he was caught.
Oh yes, I know, but I mean, I can't help feeling sorry for him. I offered to buy him out two years ago.
And he refused.
I offered much more than his worked-out concessions are worth. He could have ended his days in luxury.
Why didn't he accept your offer, madam?
Who knows? He's a foolish old man. WARNE [on monitor]: Thirteen thirty. X X One to V-Master. I'm receiving no audio response from LIZ seven nine.
Is LIZ seventy nine on thrust or stationary?
Stationary, sir. She's berthed against a section of the beacon.
Right. Now listen, Ian. If you get no reply within two minutes, you are to fire your warning rockets. And then, if necessary, stand off and use the Martian missiles.
This is Minnow fighter X X One to LIZ seven nine. You have one minute to surrender. I repeat, you have one minute to surrender, Clancey. Are you hearing me?
Now come on, now. If you don't answer my questions, I'm going to have to start getting tough with you!
Look, I think he's just stunned, Zoe. Now, look here, my man, I will not be threatened in this bullying manner! Do you understand?
Oh, no. A boy, a girl and a nut case. You can't be the pirates.
Pirates? Pirates! Oh, I see!
Oh Doctor, he's coming round.
Oh, Jamie.
Yes, I think he is coming round, girl. I only give him a quarter blast. Hey, listen, you there. Listen, she calls you Doctor. Doctor she called you. Now why did she say that?
Sheer politeness.
Are you all right, Jamie?
Come on.
Now look, I'm not going to stand any more of this nonsense. Now, I want to know who you are and where you come from? Now, come on!
It's very rude to point, you know. Especially with a gun.
I told you she was polite.
How did you get here?
Oh, we just arrived.
Oh you mean you got some sort of ship you docked on the beacon?
Not so much on it as
In it.
What, inside? Now how could you be doing that? Look, that is not possible.
Anything's possible in the Tardis, especially when he's at the controls.
Jamie, you're better.
You really expect me to swallow a story like that? Now look, if I don't get the truth out of you three comics in about ten seconds.
But it is the truth!
One
Everything we've told you is true.
Two. Three (Warne launches two rockets.)
Nine Ten! Now, come on, the truth. I want the whole truth.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Boom.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, what on Earth's that?
Someone's firing at us. Come on, let's get out of here!
Hey, wait for me!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Milo undocks from the compartment.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, there you are. Who's firing at us? Is it those pirates?
No, no! Now quiet, I want to hear this! Listen!
That was a warning shot, Clancey. You've no hope of getting away. Surrender or I'll put the next missile through your hull.
My, my, my! It's that soft-faced puppy from the Space Corps. Hang on to something, everyone, while I got to try a little trick or two on that boy.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Milo does some sharp manoeuvres, throwing everyone to the floor. A china teapot falls out of a cupboard and breaks.

Dialogue.Line: I can see you moving, Clancey. I'll give you ten seconds to turn about. Ten seconds then I'm sending a missile in.
Ten seconds! The nerve of that green-horn, saying things like that to me.
One, two, three
Don't you think it would be wiser to parley with him?
Hold your hiccups, Doctor. Milo Clancey don't take ultimatums from nobody.
Five.
Well, you can at least see what he wants.
He's going to fire a missile onto us!
I got a trick here worth ten missiles.
Nine. Ten. All right, Clancey, you had your chance.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Milo grabs a large lever and pulls, releasing a cloud of particles from Liz's stern.

Dialogue.Line: That's for that young green-horn and his new-fangled toy. Get yourself out of that one, boy.
What happened? What did you do, Mister Clancey?
My own invention, my little chickabiddy. Two tons of copper needles I just lay out beside me when one of those new-fangled spaceships gets too close for comfort.
But how do copper needles stop a spaceship?
Aye, and a missile?

Well, you see, they've all got those new-fangled computer guidance systems, you see? The argonite in the spaceship, that attracts all the copper, then all those thousand little needles, they all jigger up all their computer scanners.
What's argonite?
What is argonite?! Don't they learn you nothing at school, girl?
They didn't teach me anything about argonite.
Oh!
Have you ever heard of argonite, Doctor?

Well, from what Mister Clancey was saying, I imagine it's a metal that's used in the construction of spacecraft. Am I right? MILO: Argonite is used for, well, it's used for practically everything. It's ductile, it's tensile, it's heat-proof, it's practically indestructible.
Magnetically polarised for copper.
Ah. You mean to say that you have honestly never heard of argonite? It's the most expensive mineral in the galaxy.
I told you already. We don't come from this civilisation. We are visitors.
Aye, and I hope we're not stopping long.
Well, if that doesn't beat jumping grasshoppers. You mean to say you travel around in time as well as space?
Well, yes, yes. You've grasped the principle very well.
Hey, hey! That must be a mighty interesting thing to do.
Aye, it would be, if we knew where we were going to land up every time.
It's just a minor fault in the system. I shall DOCTOR + JAMIE: Put it right in time.
Aye.
If we ever see the Tardis again.
Oh, yes. By the way, Mister Clancey, would it be going out of your way to drop us off at the space station, please?
I can't do that. It's all in bits, isn't it.
Oh, dear. Oh, my word. Do you know where they are?
No, no, no. Only the argonite pirates know that. They're toting them off for salvage.
Oh dear, well, that will be difficult, won't it.
Hey, we shouldn't be sitting around here. We should be get getting the heck out of here before that General Hermack starts to send some more Minnows out, and I've used up all my copper needles.
Well, who's General Hermack?

General Herm? He's the Space Corps. He's trailing those pirates. He thinks I'm one of them. That's why I say he's bone-headed. Now look, let's move out of here. Excuse me. Watch out. That's it, get over there. That's it, over there. Come on, boy.
Mister Clancey.
Look, you're a good girl and you promise not to cause me trouble, you can call me Milo.
Oh, well Milo. There's one thing I don't understand.

Well you're very lucky, girl. There's about a hundred thousand things I don't understand, but I don't stand around asking fool questions about them, I do something useful. Why don't you do something useful. Why don't you make us all a pot of tea or something?
The pot was broken.
That would be lovely.
Well, there's a metal pot in that cupboard there, made of tillium.
Tillium?
Yah, that's what this whole spaceship's made of, tillium. Lasted me a lifetime round the galaxy. Makes a lousy cup of tea.
Oh, that's what I couldn't understand. Why your space ship wasn't affected by the copper needles.
What'll happen to us if one of those wee minnow things catches up with us?
Ah, don't worry lad, they won't. I'm going to go to the one place that General will never think of looking.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The cloud of copper needles is creating interference with the communications.

Dialogue.Line: He used some kind of anti-missile device, sir. Jammed all my controls.
Major Warne, can you hear me? I repeat, can you hear me? WARNE [on monitor]: Just about, sir.
You let Clancey make a complete fool of you! Are you still tracking his ship? WARNE [on monitor]: No, sir. My radar and sonar screens are out of action.
What? WARNE [on monitor]: Well, I can't sit here with just (static) I request assistance immediately, sir.
Your request is noted.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Transmission ends. Madeleine enters with a secretary.

Dialogue.Line: These are the shipping times. Send them out on transprinter to all branch stations. These are production figures and loading dates. Code them and send them to head office right away. Priority clear. Anything wrong, General?
Yes. Clancey has escaped.
How did that happen?
I don't know yet but I mean to find out. May I monopolise your video channel a while longer?
Well, of course.
Thank you. General Hermack to V forty one. PENN [on monitor]: Yes, General.
Ah, Penn. Did you pick up Major Warne's last report on your monitor? PENN [on monitor]: Some of it, sir. There was a lot of interference.
Right. Now I want the rest of the minnow fleet launched and I want LIZ seventy nine found and destroyed. Is that understood? PENN on monitor]: Yes, sir.
Report back as soon as the Minnow fleet is clear. I am not giving Milo Clancey any more chances.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Minnow fighters are launched.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor.
Yes, Jamie?
I think I'm going to be sick.
Now, now, now, Jamie. Will power, will power.
Any more tea anyone?
I'll have another cup if there's some there, Zoe. There you are, that's as good as new.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Milo has been making adjustments with a spanner.

Dialogue.Line: Milo?
Hello.
I've been watching this pressure gauge. It is just a little bit high, isn't it?
Yeah, it is a bittie. That's your thermonuclear power, you see. Yeah, it's wearing out a bit. Nothing you can do about that.
Well, except slow down. I mean, there could be a nasty explosion, couldn't there?
Ah, don't you worry, Doctor. It's a mighty strong little ship, this. They don't make ships like this these days, you know.
You can say that again.
Ah, don't you worry, lad. We haven't got far to go.
Where are we going? You haven't said.
Well, ma'am, I'll tell ya. We're going to the one place where they'll never think of looking for us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Milo turns on a scanner.

Dialogue.Line: That's the planet called Ta.
Oh? Oh yes. Is it inhabited?
Yeah, it is these days. It's the headquarters of the Issigri Mining Corporation.
Why do you say they won't bother to look for us.
Well, you see, Madeleine Issigri, who runs that show now, she's a sworn enemy of mine. Well, so I've been told. Anyway, General Hermack will think I'll go anywhere else rather than go there.
Yes, but if she's a sworn enemy, won't she give you away?
We won't be announcing our arrival, Doctor. We'll just lie low there until that old Space Corps gets tired of looking for us.
It doesn't look as though there's anything there. This side is just desert.

No, no, there's no surface life on Ta, girl. There's too much ultra- violet radiation. Don't you worry, don't you worry. We'll be all right. We'll be a mile underground as long as I can fall into my old landing pad.
Oh, you've been there before, have you?
Certainly have, certainly have. Me and my old partner, Dom Issigri, god rest his poor tired old soul, we turned that whole planet into a piece of Gruyere cheese between us.
Gruyere cheese.
Jamie, here. Mining! I see. For argonite, presumably.

Yeah, that's right, argonite. One of the richest strikes we ever found. Took us about ten years to drill that clean. Well, I'd better try to find this old entry shaft then. Now, you'd better brace yourselves. Hang onto something. My landing pad's ain't as good as they used to be.
Who cares as long as it's quick.
Bring the ship in on pad three. I'll join you there, Penn. PENN [on monitor]: Yes, sir.
I'm sorry your stay was so short, General.
Well, I hope on my next visit, my duties will be less pressing.
So do I. Where do you go from now?
Well, first of all I must get young Warne out of that fix he's got himself into. Then I must collect my pickets from the beacons. And after that, Lobos. MADELEINE: Lobos!
Hmm mmm.
Milo Clancey's base?
The pirate's base. Those beacons they've been breaking up will be heading there. With a little bit of luck, we shall be able to wipe out the whole nest in one operation.
Well, I hope you do. Some of my crews are demanding arms in case they're attacked.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: On his way to the door, Hermack notices a model of a sleek black spaceship.

Dialogue.Line: Is that a, is that a Beta Dart?
Yes. Yes, our company's just bought two. They're our fastest freighters.
Ah. I must bear that in mind. The pirates have a Beta Dart. I should hate to knock out one of your ships by mistake.
Well I don't think that's likely. All our freighters show the Issigri nose-cone when they're in commission.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She slides a pattern nose cone onto the model.

Dialogue.Line: I designed it myself.
Ah, very distinctive. How much does it cost?
Oh, a hundred million credits upwards. Depends on the fittings. Why do you ask?
I was just wondering where Milo Clancey got a hundred million credits.
I see. You think he got it by selling the stolen argonite.
Why not? It's logical. There's an illicit market for them on Rita Magnum, I hear.
Yes, but I'm sure you're wrong about Milo Clancey.
Are you? I'm not. He's selling the stuff and professing poverty as a cover. If I find those beacons sections on line for Lobos, he'll not live to enjoy his money.
Goodbye, General.
Goodbye, Miss Issigri. Thank you for your hospitality.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Liz lands with a big bump, throwing everyone around again.

Dialogue.Line: Nice smooth landing, after all.
Smooth? What do you call a rough landing?
What's the matter with you, sonny? Are you getting soft or something?
Just let me get my feet back on the ground, that's all.
You stay right here where you're safe, boy.
Safe? Is that what you call this?
You want us to stay here?
Yeah. I'm thinking of your own safety.
Why?

Well, we're a mile underground here. This is the old freighter dock. And there's nothing to see, there's nowhere to go, it's just a whole maze of argonite tunnels, and if you go in there, well, even I mayn't be able to find you again. You stay right here in this ship.
Just a minute, where are you going?
I've got to go to the generator room. I think one of their rockets must have gone through my transmitter unit. That radio there's whistling like some sort of hysterical canary.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Milo leaves with his tool bag.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, do you believe him?
I don't know, Jamie. What do you think?
Well, he never did explain how he turned up the way he did, did he? And that Space Corp ship was chasing him.
True. But I think we've got to trust him, Jamie. If we leave this ship, we'll never ever have a chance of finding the Tardis again.
Well I don't see we've got much of a chance anyway. Look, it's up there in space somewhere on a bit of that beacon heading for I don't know where.
A blast furnace, I imagine. I think I think the pirates are probably going to take the pieces and melt them down for the for the argonite. The trouble is, we can't guess where their headquarters is.
There's no need to guess, Doctor. It's easy enough to work out.
What?
Applied mathematics.
Applied? Oh, I see. You've been messing about again, have you?
Oh well, if you don't want to know what I've discovered.
No, no, no, no, no. Come along, surprise us.
This was the position of our bit of beacon when Milo first saw us. I got the figures from the computer.
Oh yes.
And this was our position eight minutes later when he docked along side.
Yes, circle fourteen. Yes, go on.
Well, from this data it was simple enough to work out our original position and course. Do you see?
Yes, except that after my little experiment, we veered rather violently off that course.
Ah yes
Yes, but I allowed for that. Look!
Oh.
Oh.
Electromagnetic waves are always at right-angles to the direction of propagation, and, as you know, travel at one hundred and eighty six thousand, two hundred and eighty two miles per second.
Do they really? How interesting. Well, what's the answer?
Here!
What?
If we'd stayed on our original course, the Tardis would have landed within ten miles of where we are now. Except, of course, it would still be up there because we weren't travelling quite so fast.
Oh, bless my soul! Yes, of course. Yes, as you say, a simple calculation. I should have thought of that myself.
Yes, I wonder why you didn't?
Did all that talk mean that the Tardis is going to land somewhere around here?
Jamie, it's all here, written down. It's as plain as a pike-staff.
Aye, well, in that case, the pirates are going to be round here too!
Yes, Jamie, you're right.
Do you think Milo's one of them and that's why he landed here?
Yes, I think it's possible.
Aye, he seemed to know all about them, didn't he? Look, I think we ought to get out of here before he comes back.
Yes, so do I. We don't even know if he has gone to the generator room. He might just have gone to get his gang.
Aye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor checks outside the cabin.

Dialogue.Line: All right. All right, but if the Tardis has landed here we'll have to find it anyway. Come on, you two, but for heaven's sake don't make a noise on the ladder.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie falls over something.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie!
We're not on the ladder yet, are we.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In a nearby tunnel, Dervish approaches a door with two other pirates.

Dialogue.Line: Wait here!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He enters the cavern HQ where Caven is at a communications desk.

Dialogue.Line: What's the panic, Caven?
No panic.
Well, you know what I mean. I got a Red emergency flash.
I wanted to talk to you, Dervish.
Well?
What's the position at the plant?
We've just started on the last section of Alpha Two.
Leave it.
Leave it?
Suledin's capable of taking change down there, isn't he?
Well yes, but
Right, when you've finished your flight service, I want you to take the ship out.
Me? Where?
The Alpha Four sections are being re-routed.
Re-route?
To Lobos.
Lobos? But that's impossible!
When I give an order, nobody says it's impossible, Dervish.
Well, do you know how far Lobos is? I mean, the beacon rockets will have to be re-fuelled.
That's right. That's exactly what I want you to do.
Yeah, but the Space Corps have got a V-ship and a flight of Minnows up there. It's too dangerous!
It has to be done. They've got to be drawn off.
Well, why can't you do it, then? You're the master pilot. I'm only supposed to be the engineer.
I've got to do things down here.
Yes, so I've got to go and risk my life while

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Caven draws a gun.

Dialogue.Line: You keep arguing, Dervish, and Suledin will be having your job permanently. Now are you going to take that ship out or aren't you?
Yes, of course, Caven. I was only just trying to point out the dangers, that's all.
Well, now you're in more danger here than you ever will be in space.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An alarm sounds.

Dialogue.Line: It's the perimeter alarm.
Intruders in perimeter tunnel nine. Perimeter tunnel nine.
Alert the guards. I'm coming down.
Is it the Space Corps?
I don't know, but whoever it is, we can deal with them in the tunnel complex. Now get moving!
Right

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Jamie and Zoe have arrived in the dark, dank, fissure-strewn lower tunnels.

Dialogue.Line: I'm sure we should have turned right back there.
We did turn right.
I mean earlier. We seem to be getting deeper.
What do you think, Doctor? Should we go on or turn back?
I think we should have done as Milo told us. He said we'd get lost.
The tunnels probably run for hundreds of miles.
Well, if they do, we'll never get ourselves out.
Shush. Just a minute, Jamie.
What?
I can hear something.
There it is. A buzzing noise.
Where's it coming from?
Seems to be up ahead there.
Well, that's all right again, right as rain. Hey, where are you? Zoe? Doctor? They ain't here. Oh, why can't some people do what they're told. I guess I'd better go out and try and find them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Strapping on his gun and taking a haversack from a cupboard, Milo leaves.
Zoe, Jamie and the Doctor have landed in a heap on a hard surface.

Dialogue.Line: Oh Doctor, are you all right?
No.
What's the matter?
Just a minute.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes a broken packet from his back trouser pocket.

Dialogue.Line: What are you carrying drawing pins for?
I like drawing pins. Ouch. Normally.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Caven puts his gun away.

Dialogue.Line: Right. They won't give us any more trouble.
Oh, my leg!
Are you all right?
I must have twisted it when I landed. Oh, now where are we?
It looks like some sort of a prison cell.
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Someone groans in the gloom.

Dialogue.Line: What's that?
Oh, Doctor, there's something over there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Up above, Caven and his men leave, and Milo appears to go and look down into the shaft. The Doctor investigates the groaning and finds someone lying against the wall.

Dialogue.Line: Oh dear.
What is it?
Look.
Hey, it's that chap from the beacon. The one that was shooting at us.
Yes, he's injured. Look.
I think it's his shoulder. I think it's only a bruise. It's not broken. Lift him up, very gently. What's this?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor sniffs at an earthenware bowl.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, that's all right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor wets his handkerchief in the water and puts it to Sorba's forehead.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, he's coming around.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Caven is using his transmitter.

Dialogue.Line: Come in, Beta Buccaneer. DERVISH [on monitor]: I want permission to return to base. Caven, do you hear me? I'm bringing this ship in.
Calm down, man. Report your position. DERVISH [on monitor]: We're forty three thousand miles out, on course for the beacon sections.

Well, you should be among them in twenty minutes. What's wrong? Why the panic? DERVISH [on monitor]: We're running our heads into a trap, Caven. The Space Corp cruiser is less than three hours away, and on a convergent course.
Those beacon sections have got to be diverted to Lobos. How long will that take? DERVISH [on monitor]: It will take at least two hours. We just can't do it on time.
You'll have to, Dervish. Just find some way of cutting the time. DERVISH [on monitor]: Those Minnow fighters will blast us to bits. I'm bringing the ship in!
Now wait, don't be so impulsive.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Caven holds up a wired cylinder.

Dialogue.Line: Surely you recognise this, Dervish? You designed it. DERVISH [on monitor: Well, it's a UHF detonator. What are you playing at, Caven?
I'm not playing at all. It is a detonator, and it is keyed to a charge right under the atomic drives of the Buccaneer. DERVISH [on monitor]: I don't believe it. You you're bluffing.

If you think I'm bluffing, just you try turning back. You see, Dervish, you've got a fair chance of escaping the V-ship and the Minnows, but you've no chance at all of getting away from this. DERVISH [on monitor]: All right, Caven.
I knew you wouldn't let me down. Report as soon as you reach the sections.
All set. Operational? Right. Thank you. Major Warne's just come aboard, sir. He's coming up to the bridge.
Good. Bridge to Power Room. We're under way again. Half boost. Set course for Lobos, Penn.
Very good, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Warne enters.

Dialogue.Line: Thanks for the rescue, sir.
Ah. What happened to you, anyway?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Warne shows him a piece of metal.

Dialogue.Line: Copper needles?

Yes, sir. I warned Clancey I was about to fire one of the Martian missiles. I pressed the button and the next thing I ran slap into a cloud of these. The computer blew and the whole machine just stopped.
Copper! Of course! Attracted by the argonite hull of the Minnow.
Yes, sir. It won't happen again, sir.
It had better not. When one old man in a worn out junk-heap like the Liz makes a complete fool of a highly trained fighter pilot in a sophisticated flight ship I
Yes, sir. Well, I'll hit him with a deflection shot next time, sir. I worked out how to do it. You see
Never mind the theories, Major. With a bit of luck, Clancey will not be able to exploit your limitations again because we shall take him on the ground.
On the ground, sir?
Yes, we're on course for Lobos, the headquarters of the Clancey Mining Company.
You think that's where he's gone?
I'm sure of it. Apart from Ta, it's the next nearest planet. Yes, that's where Clancey will be and that's where we shall find our evidence. The sections of Beacon Alpha Four.
Are you feeling better?
You were on the beacon. What are you doing here?
Oh, look, it's all right. We're friends.
Friends? You led my men into a trap.
We were in the same trap ourselves. The pirates left us for dead.
I thought you were decoys.
Oh look, we wouldn't be here now if we were helping them.
Then how did you get off the beacon?
Well, well, it's a long story, but the important thing is to escape from here now.
Do you think I haven't tried? That shaft is the only way in. It's impossible to get out.
Oh, no. There's another entrance here somewhere.
I've searched every inch of this cell. Solid rock.
There's a hidden door. The problem of course, is going to be finding it.
There's no door, believe me. You're only wasting your time.
No, no, no, no. There's obviously a less painful way of getting in here so there must be a way of getting out.
What makes you so sure? I mean, it could be a sort of tomb.
Aye, a burial pit.
Look. Water, in a fragile bowl. Well that couldn't have been thrown down that chute, now could it?
Caven, I've got the crews out realigning the auxiliary rockets for Lobos, but one of the beacon sections is missing.

That's not possible. DERVISH [on monitor]: Look, there's only seven sections here. There should be eight. I checked back right along the flight path, but there's not a sign of it. It's completely disappeared.

Nothing disappears in space. Even if the rocket exploded there'd be debris along the flight path. DERVISH [on monitor]: There's no debris, there's nothing. It's completely disappeared. The scanner shows zero find.
But that's crazy. There must be some explanation. DERVISH [on monitor]: Oh yeah, there's an explanation all right, but you're not going to like it.
Well, come on, come on. DERVISH [on monitor]: Somebody must have engineered the section out of its flight path.
How could anybody manage that? DERVISH [on monitor]: Well, I don't know.
Wait a minute. That space guard. The one we took off the beacon. DERVISH [on monitor]: Lieutenant Sorba?
Yes. He said something about seeing strangers on board. Perhaps he wasn't raving. Perhaps we've got competition, Dervish. Someone trying to cut themselves in, hey?
Just a minute. Look, I've got to go. Once of the spider teams wants picking up.
Right. I'll question Sorba about these strangers he saw. Call in as soon as you get the sections on the new flight path.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Jamie are carefully checking the walls.

Dialogue.Line: They're mad. It's solid rock.
When the Doctor gets an idea, nobody can change his mind.
Oh look Doctor, this is doing no good at all.
Patience, Jamie, patience.
You'll not find anything. We've been over it three times already.
It's got to be here. Look.
Aye, I know. Cracks in the wall.
Yes, but see the way they run.
There are marks like that all over the place.
Yes, well, we're going to go on trying.
Now what's he doing?
Oh, search me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is listening to the wall through his stethoscope.

Dialogue.Line: There's got to be a control unit here somewhere. Just a question of locating it, that's all.
What sort of control unit?
Shush, shush. Just a minute.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor taps one piece of wall.

Dialogue.Line: Ah ha. Yes. Yes, it's under there.
What's under there?
An audio lock.
An audio lock!
Oh now, wait a minute, what's an audio lock?

Well, they were used on safes, Jamie. Combination locks became a little too easy to open when burglars took to taking miniature computers with them on their expeditions. Now I have my tuning forks here somewhere.
What are you going to do with a tuning fork?
I usually carry them with. Ah, yes. Here we are, now then, get these sorted out. Right.
Which end did he land on when you fell down that shaft?
Contact ahead, sir!
What contact?
It could be the sections of Alpha Four, sir. There are seven objects moving quite slowly.
If it's the beacon, sir, there should be eight sections.
What's their course, Penn?
Approximately the same as ours, sir. The convergence is less than half a degree.
Then the flight destination must be Lobos. Clancey's home planet. We've got him, Ian.
We can't be sure it is the beacon, sir. Well, we counted eight sections originally.
Just a minute. What's that on the edge of the scanner?
I'm trying to get a fix on it now, sir. It's just come into frame.
It must be the missing section.
No, sir, it's too big and it's moving too fast. I think it's some kind of ship.
Out there? No, with any luck it's the pirates.
She seems to be circling.
Can't you magnify that signal, Penn?
No, sir. She's right out on the fringe.
Ian, get down to the Minnow deck. I want you ready to go as soon as we've got an identification.
Right, sir.
Power room? I want main boost for as long as we can hold it. Don't worry about those beacon sections, Penn. That ship is our target.
Right, sir. Shall I get your (unintelligible) sir?
Not yet. Go to half speed. General Hermack. I want all crews at emergency stations. I repeat, all crews at emergency stations. WARNE [on monitor]: X X 2 ready to go. Any news yet, V-Master?
The range is down to forty minutes. Penn has just made a positive identification. It is a Beta Dart, so they can still outrun us. WARNE [on monitor]: She won't outrun a Minnow, sir.
Sir, she's boosting. She must have spotted us.
Right! V-Master to X X 2. Blast away! WARNE [on monitor]: Right, sir. I'll bring back a chunk of her.
There's a Space Corps lieutenant in the punishment cell under tunnel nine. He's injured. I want him brought here for questioning.
Yes, sir.
Here's the audio-lock tuner key.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard leaves.

Dialogue.Line: This is Beta Buccaneer. Caven! There's a Minnow fighter on our tail.
Only one? What's his range?
Thirty minutes, but closing fast. And we're on maximum boost.
Can't you hold him off long enough to reach the camouflage cone?
That's just what I'm going to try and do.
X X 2 to V-Master. I seem to have lost contact. Can you steer me in, please?
Stand by. Major Warne's lost her.
I thought he would, sir. She's doubled round.
I'll switch it through on audio. You get an RC track for him to track on.
Very good, sir. This is Navigator Penn to X X 2. Are you reading me?
Yes, I just don't have a nice picture of that Beta Dart any more.
Okay, sir. Now, if you steer round seven under TDC. Now thirty seven degrees up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is a detached rocket nose cone with the livery of the Issigri mining company floating in space. The Beta Dart lines up with it and drifts forward so it locks onto it.

Dialogue.Line: She should be in range now, sir.
Right. I can see her on the visual scanners.
Switch video through here. We might as well all enjoy this.
Cutting you in now, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hermack is aghast.

Dialogue.Line: That's an Issigri ship! Flash out! Flash out! WARNE [on monitor]: Contact broken.
You didn't fire at her? WARNE [on monitor]: No, sir. I was just in range when I got the flash out. What's gone wrong?
We nearly wiped out one of the Issigri Mining Company's new freighters. WARNE [on monitor]: You mean to say that wasn't the pirate ship? Then where's it got to?
I don't know. Anyway, we'll abort the mission. You'd better return.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is busy with his tuning fork.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, look, Doctor, will you stop it?
What's that noise? It's getting on everybody's nerves.
You want to get out of here, don't you?
Oh, that's not going to get us out.
Yes, Jamie, it is! An audio lock is a simple solenoid switch which is only activated by a particular sound. It's just a question of finding it, that's all.
Oh look, I can't stand any more!
Jamie! Jamie!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie snatches the tuning fork and throws it down. A section of wall slides open.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie, you found the right note!
Oh come on, we can get away now.
Oh no, we can't.
What?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Milo Clancey is on the other side, with his gun.

Dialogue.Line: I've been trying to find my way in here for the last hour. Now, come on now!
Come on where?
What's the matter with you, boy? You don't think I'm in cahoots with the pirates, do you?
Well they're here, you know. We've seen them.
I know. They've got nothing to do with me.
Well, it might help if you didn't point that thing in our direction.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Milo lowers his gun.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, come on now. If I was in cahoots with the pirates, why would I be trying to rescue you?
We don't know that you are trying to rescue us.
No.
Oh, that's a fine thing to say, isn't it. Didn't I get you off that beacon? You would have died if I hadn't helped you then.
Aye, you only got us off of there because you were curious to know who we were.
And that Space Corp ship opened fire on you.
Hmm.

If that don't beat jumping grasshoppers. You listen to me, you three sourpusses. You're only in this pickle now because you did the very thing I told you not to do. You went wandering off into these mine workings. I've had a whale of a time trying to find you, and if you want to get out of here alive, Milo Clancey is the only person who can show you the way. Now, you either come with me, or am I going to leave you here to rot?
Well, well, well, yes, yes, if you put it that way.
Right. Good thinking. It's about time one of you showed a bit of sense. Who's this?
My name is Sorba. Lieutenant Sorba.
Aye. The pirates took him prisoner when they attacked the beacon.
Oh, there's no love lost between me and the Space Corp, Sonny Jim, but, well, you'd better come with us, I guess.
Shush, shush, there's somebody coming.
Keep back there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They all crouch against the wall as the footsteps come closer.

Dialogue.Line: The door's open!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two guards rush in. Milo shoots one.

Dialogue.Line: Take his gun. It might come in useful.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The other guard escapes.

Dialogue.Line: Tarnation take it! A couple of years ago I'd have nailed him before he got ten yards.
What, you mean he got away?
Aye he did. It means we're in real trouble. There'll be guards swarming round that tunnel now like a buzz of bees!
Well, we'd better get away. hadn't we?
We sure had. Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An alarm sounds.

Dialogue.Line: What's that?
I told you. That's the alarm signal. Now, come on, let's get out of here. Quick.
Yes, all right.
Where are they now?
They've gone through into the small bore workings on level eight. I've sent five men after them.
I thought I told you to cordon off those lower caverns.
Yes, well, they got through somehow. They must have used one of the old ventilators. They seem to know their way better than our own guards.
Milo Clancey.
What was that Chief?
There's only one man who can get through these tunnels like that. All right, Joubert, I'm coming down! I want these people either caught or killed. I don't care which, you understand?
Just a minute, Chief. They've just passed the perimeter eye on level six.
Level six already? All right, listen. I want every man up to level three. Use the elevators. I want every entrance to that level sealed off, and it had better done by the time I get there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Milo is leading everyone up a steep narrow section.

Dialogue.Line: Milo?
What?
Can we rest a moment?
Why?
No, no, don't bother with me. I'm all right.
Oh well, I want a rest, anyway. It's this climbing.
Well, just for a minute, then. Remember, they're closing in on us all the time we stay here.
Oh dear. Where are we heading for, Milo?
The Issigri Mining Company. We got to get to their headquarters. It's only a couple of levels from here now.
But didn't you say that Madeleine Issigri was your sworn enemy?
Yeah, well, I thought she was. I thought it was her lot that was behind all this piracy trying to do me out of business.
You've changed your mind. Why?

Well, I thought Madeleine blamed me for her father's death. Poor old Dom. He just disappeared. Years ago now. I wasn't even here at the time. And then all this piracy started and Madeleine started to find argonite in workings that Dom and I had abandoned years ago. Well, it all seemed to fit together somehow.
Yes, well, it fits together a bit too well, if you ask me. Aren't we jumping out of the frying pan into the fire?
No! No! When I followed you down that shaft I recognised the leader of these pirates. He's a murderous criminal called Maurice Caven.
You know this man?
Yeah, I've seen his picture on home planet. He's notorious.
Someone's coming.
Come on, let's get out of here. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Milo and the Doctor are almost carrying Sorba. Jamie is bringing up the rear, carrying the guard's gun.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, come on there. Come on.
It's no use.
Well come on. We're almost there now.
I'll never make it. You go on.
No, we've got you this far, we're not going to leave you here.
We can't carry him, Milo.
Oh Doctor, they're not far behind us!
Aye, well they won't get much further, don't worry.
No, Jamie. Come back.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie goes back down the tunnel

Dialogue.Line: He won't hold them off for long. He got no recharge units for that gun.
Oh Doctor, can't you think of something?
I'm not a magician Zoe, I. What's this?
It's an old power distributor box, I think. We got one on every level.
Really? Oh. Well, I wonder if it's connected up? Oh!
Yes, it's connected.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie takes cover behind a boulder and shoots an approaching pirate. Caven and the others take cover.

Dialogue.Line: Zoe, attach these to that metal ring there, do you see?
Yes, all right, but hurry, Doctor.
I am hurrying!
What's this contraption supposed to do Doctor, trip them up?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Caven waves his men forward. Jamie shoots another pirate. Then he runs out of power so he throws the gun away and creeps back along the tunnel carefully. The power cable runs across the tunnel floor.

Dialogue.Line: Right. Right, over the wire.
What?
Come on. That's it. Now, I'm going to I'm going to test it, so stand clear.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor flicks a switch.

Dialogue.Line: Is that all?
Yes, I think it's working. Right, now you two, you carry along. I'll stay here and help Jamie.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe and Milo leave, supporting Sorba.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor! They're right behind me.
Jamie, wait!
What?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor turns off the power.

Dialogue.Line: Right. Look! Stand clear.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie steps over the cable and the Doctor switches the power back on.

Dialogue.Line: Here they come!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Jamie run after Milo and Zoe. The first pirate reaches the cable. There is a flash and he falls.

Dialogue.Line: What is this?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Milo, Zoe, Jamie and Sorba enter.

Dialogue.Line: I thought it was some sort of joke when my company guards told me that Milo Clancey was on his way up in the main elevator. Who are your friends?
No joke, girl. Now look, will you do one thing for me before you start asking me any fool questions?
What?
I want you to get onto General Hermack, and get him to get that V-ship here as soon as he can.
Why?
There you go, asking questions! Because you're harbouring a nest of vipers down there in those mine workings, and they're on their way up here at this very moment.
He means that the argonite pirates are using the old mine workings as a secret hideout.
Argonite pirates? Oh really.
Oh, child, will you listen to me!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Caven destroys the power box.

Dialogue.Line: Right, come on!
Wait! I never agreed to anything like this.
If you don't like it, step outside for a moment.
I don't want any more killing.
Too bad.
I warn you, Caven, don't overreach yourself.
I never do that.
Well then, just remember I'm still running this operation.
Are you? I do all the dirty work. The space piracy, the capital larceny
The first degree homicides!
Right, Clancey. While all you do is sit there looking pretty and count the money. But that doesn't mean to say you're not guilty.
Maybe, but I never agreed to murder.
Well, you'd better agree to it, because if we don't get rid of these snoops, we'll both end up in a nirvan chamber.
I don't want them killed! There must be some other solution.
Yes, there's just got to be. CAVEN: Dyce.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Caven turns away, and the Doctor and Milo realise Jamie is going to attack a guard. They grab him.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie!
Let go of me!
You don't stand a chance.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie relaxes. Caven whispers to one of his men, who goes over to the prisoners.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, hurry up. Out of the line. Move yourselves.
All right, there's no need to shout.
What are you going to do with them?
Don't worry, they're not going to be shot.
I don't trust you, Caven.
I told Fraze to lock them away under the dock complex. Ask him if you don't believe me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Co. are taken from the room.

Dialogue.Line: What made you change your mind all of a sudden?
I had a better idea, that's all.
Oh yes?
